The Underpass Echo

Hark—the underpass's hollow hum curls down and settles deep,  
Clang—shush! the alley answers ring,  
Glimfen-glow and bramble-breath coil low where shadows keep deep,  
Footfall flips; the dripping drip replies and rings.  

So leathered lantern-lungs are strapped, each stride a steady arm,  
Tick—toll, clang—bell,  
They whisper spryxe-scripts and bind the courage-knot warm,  
They call the name—Grindlehorn! and toll the warning-bell.  

Down under arch of dripping bricks the hunters bear on stone,  
Whump—crash—hiss! the shaggle-thrum's roar,  
Bran's blade—a bristle-spark—drove true and sent the thrumble down on stone,  
Crack—thud! the hollow answered final roar.  

Homeward with laurel-lumps they go, lamp-glint on glove and home,

The Glowgrume

poem:
Shudderfloom Underpass

Underpass hush-hung, shudderfloom sighs through steel and seam,
Clang! clack! — the tunnel goes boom.
Posters peel, a gutter-whisper names Goxthorn in the breath,
Hear the warning cans go boom.

We gird our gristle-gloves and marchumble boots on marrow-stone,
Hush—thrum-thrum, our kettle-heart.
I sling Riftcleave, gleam-barbed, and spit a spark to steady arm,
Thump—step out; we carry kettle-heart.

Under iron-arch it brays, a brum-breathed coil of brash,

Goxthorn lunges, ragged rasp and gutter-song of ring,

Homeward, boot and brass-blood warm, lantern-lilt leads the lane,
Feastwheedle clink—our bonfire hum.

poem:
The Jammerwump

In inkfall hush at spooltime's hour,
a clack—clack—alarm did chime;
From feed-tray fold crept glint and glower,
it hummed of jam and grime.

We fetched spoolspanners, grease and tack,
with snick-snap set up tight;
We humpled the wheelers, nudged the back,
and primed the rollers tight.

Out leapt Gumblax — clack, whrrr, and spit,
its teeth of tack and tin;
I raised the flap-saber, snick and grit,
we snapped its gnash to tin.

We heaped the prints in feastfold fan,
a soft—soft—huzzah did chime;
Inkfeathered leaves and paper-pride began,
and inkfall hush kissed chime.

The Music-Room Merrin

Hush in the music-room where twimbrels twine and sing,  
Clang!—tick, click—the rafters sigh in gloom,  
Silken strings shudder, brass-breath bellows, plectrums fling,  
Mind the muttering mantel, mind the creeping gloom.

Gather gear—strum-saber, timpied pike and pinglatch bright,  
Tink!—tune and tighten—brace the ring,  
Fingers furl the fret, feet press pedals, steadying the night,  
Strike—let steel and string agree and ring.

Out burst the cupboard-curse—the Strumwight Grimbash, snarled and bound,

Harploom hisses, bassbones batter, cymbal-sparks cascade and pound,

Home with harp and horn we hurry, cheeks aflush with flame,  
Tra-la!—cups clink—glad echoes home,  
Merrifall of metronomes march; bright banners breathe our name,  
Twimbrels twine anew and trill—the music-room is home.

poem:
Layover Bay

Mark the layover bay—gloomble gusts at brine and blur of day,  
Whump! whee! the quay goes clatter, clack and hollow drum,  
Mist-motes mutter, moor-mothers whisper warnings through the day,  
Hiss—hush—heed the hollow, hear the heart that thunders drum.

We sling trindle ropes, belted packs bump bright on shoulder bows,  
Clang! clink!—pack and pray, press forward to the salt-slimed shore,  
Quick-quarters, quench the quiver—sharpen, stitch, set snug our woes,  
Song-sway, stomp, we steady feet and step and stride for shore.

Sudden—Grawlith, bristle-bellied, barges up, a barnacled bane,  
Crash! goes the surf, the brine spits, sizzle, spit and ravenous roar,  
We swing horn-hewn bay-blades—steel bites scale and slough the bane,  
Clang, gurgle—one last gurgled groan, then silence swallows roar.

Feastle fires flick, folk fold round, flagons froth and embers bloom,  
Huzzah! horns heave homeward—hollers lift the lamp-lit bay,  
Hands clap, heels hop, hale hymns stitch the marrow from the gloom,  
We sing the caution into courage—again we tread the layover bay.

The Creep-Crow's Counsel

Whump! the alley answers, cobbles clack toward glade.

The Wishway Ballad

Hush — the wishway winds, wind-worn and sly,

Root-murm, leaf-lisp; a want-wisp asks why,  
Swish — be warned of bramble-bow bent to the way.

poem:
The Mornfloom

At dawn the damp did drape the dell,
shh — the floom crept close, a feather-hiss of mist;
It pinched the porch and pooled the bell,
a hush that hummed and hid the mist.

I buckled boots and braced my back to go,

I set the glarebrand's hilt; it hummed and glowed,
clack! — the scabbard sang of cold.

The floomfolk fled, their flags half-folded fast,

It gnashed with gloombite teeth and fog-thorned blast,
shoom! I struck — it stilled that roar.

Homeward we marched with mantles bent and bright,
and sang, clink-clank, mistmirth to the dell;
Our boots beat bravely where the breath broke white,
At dawn the damp again draped the dell
